i mean, i see what you're saying, but the point i raised spreads across many professions. whether that[.] tech, research and academia, business management, finances, the arts, politics, etc. the same idea applies. if a given profession is seeing a different-than-expected spread of race/gender/etc., then i think it[.] important to look into why that is. if it[.] because of some general preferences of a given group, then it[.] not a big deal. if there[.] some actual barrier of entry, such as a large amount of bigotry in some part of the industry, then something obviously should be done.

i'm not trying to say that what i said is for sure what[.] happening, but it[.] something we need to consider. it[.] one of those subtle, wide-scale issues that we've been trying to tackle recently as a society. full force, blatant bigotry is a lot less common today, so any forward movement for society is going to be about the more subtle points. for example, it called for the investigation of the perceived wage gap between men and women in america\* and also brought to light the much more pressing issue (in my opinion) of the wage gap between the races.

but another point i'd like to bring up is that people might not even know they like doing something before they're turned off by it, possible because they feel they won't be good at it. imagine the countless number of people in their 40s that would've loved tech jobs if only they felt it was something they could do back then. personally, it took me until my senior year of college as a geology major to realize i actually really liked programming. before then, i didn't really try since i felt like i wouldn't have been good enough for it. mine is not a racial issue, just an example of how "liking doing it" might not be enough, because there are likely a lot of people who don't ever try it. 

i mean, one major reason for a well-rounded education is so that children can learn what they like and don't like, and given that minority groups are sometimes disadvantaged when it comes to early education, this in itself could be stunting the growth of countless industries. and for that reason, it[.] something we should be looking into, if not actively trying to fix it already.

this got a lot longer than i expected, and a bit tangential. oops.

^\* which was found to be drastically narrower than the initial statistic showed; i believe the official report said the real gap was closer to . 95 to a dollar, at least accounting for observed and explained effects.
